title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in different subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in different subsections, including the requirement for warrants to be issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. This includes district courts of the United States and United States courts of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense. The jurisdiction for issuing warrants is specified in Title 18 of the United States Code, including district courts, courts of appeals, and state courts with criminal jurisdiction. The jurisdiction for issuing warrants is specified in Title 18 of the United States Code, including district courts, courts of appeals, and state courts with criminal jurisdiction. Assistance can be provided by a court authorized to issue search warrants, with specific criteria outlined in section 3127(2)(A) of the code. The jurisdiction for issuing warrants is specified in Title 18 of the United States Code, including district courts, courts of appeals, and state courts with criminal jurisdiction. Assistance can be provided by a court authorized to issue search warrants, with specific criteria outlined in section 3127(2)(A) of the code. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions can be executed upon application authorized by the Department of Justice, allowing Federal judges to issue necessary orders. Federal judges may issue orders to assist foreign authorities in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including search warrants and orders for electronic communications or records. The text discusses the types of orders that federal judges can issue to assist foreign authorities in criminal investigations, including search warrants, orders for electronic communications, pen register or trap and trace device orders, and orders requiring testimony or document production. Federal judges can appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance, administer oaths, and receive documents or other things. A person appointed by federal judges can oversee the gathering of testimony, statements, or documents in response to a foreign authority's request. They have the power to issue orders for appearance, administer oaths, and receive documents. Requests can be filed in the district where the person resides, where the documents are located, or in any district where the person or documents may be found. A search warrant requested by a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense would be punishable by imprisonment in the United States. A Federal judge may issue a search warrant under this section if the foreign offense would be punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the United States. The warrant can be served anywhere in the United States, and foreign authorities can still seek assistance under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to obtaining assistance in a criminal investigation or prosecution under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code, including definitions for "Federal judge" and "foreign authority." The curr_chunk adds definitions related to obtaining assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code, including definitions for "Federal judge" and "foreign authority." It also designates competent authorities for making requests for assistance pursuant to agreements or treaties with the United States regarding criminal matters. The curr_chunk pertains to foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
